Ritual.ab: agar šnūman nōgnāwar bēd ahurahe mazdā̊ raēuuatō xᵛarənaŋᵛhatō aməṣ̌anąm spəṇtanąm miϑrahe vouru.gaōiiaōitōiš rāmanasca xᵛā strahe.
"If it is the šnūman nōgnāwar, (he has to recite) ahurahe mazdā̊ raēuuatō xᵛarənaŋᵛhatō aməṣ̌anąm spəṇtanąm miϑrahe vouru.gaōiiaōitōiš rāmanasca xᵛā strahe ..."
zōt ud rāspīg čašm pad ātaxš ud barsom dārišn zōt yaϑā ahū vairiiō zaōta frā.mē. mrūte rāspīg yaϑā ahū vairiiō yō zaōta frā.mē mrūtē zōt aϑā ratuš kardan

"Both, the zōt and the rāspīg, turn their gaze to the fire and the barsom. The zōt (should say): yaϑā ahū vairiiō zaōta frā.mē mrūte, the rāspīg : yaϑā ahū vairiiō yō zaōta frā.mē mrūtē and the rāspīg should answer aϑā ratuš"

Quotations.ab: ka zōt pad wāz-gīrišnīh ī pad frastuiiē be šawēd aṣ̌əm vohū 3 frauuarānē mazdaiiasnō cē gāh dārēd ud šnūman abāz ōšmurēnd u-š wāz frāz-gīrišn [[ka]] az bunīh

ka [rāspīg] wāz gīrēd be ka har 3 wēnēd tā nē šāyēd zōt ātaxš ud barsom pas ka ēk wēnēd ā šāyēd ast kē ēdōn gōwēd hād u- š [az] bunīh ēk wēnēd šāyēd pas ka wāng ašnawēd šāyēd ka wāz gīrēd ā-š wāng ēdōn kunišn kū ka-z pad tan-ē kard ašnawē ud ka pad ēw-kardagīh frāz ašnawēnd ā-z šāyēd
"When the zōt reaches the wāz gīrišnīh at the frastuiiē (he has to recite) three Aṣ̌əm Vohū (Y0.9). They should recite the frauuarāne mazdaiiasnō that contains the gāh and the šnūman and he takes wāz

When the rāspīg takes the wāz, if he does not see all the three, that is, zōt, fire and barsom, then it is not allowed. Afterwards, if he just sees one, it is allowed. There is one who says: 'Yes, if at the beginning, he sees just one (of the three things) , then it is allowed. Then, if he hears the voice (of the zōt, it is allowed.' When he takes the wāz, he has to raise his voice so that it can be heard when recited alone; and when they hear it (when recited) in unison, it is also allowed."
Cf. N19.9, Kotwal and Kreyenbroek, 1995: pp. 112-113 (Mss. 300, 360, 370):

hād pad hamāg cāštag pad ān zamān bawēd ka zōt pad frastuiiē ī bun be šawēd tā ka zōt pad wāz-gīrišnīh pad frastuiiē ī bun be šud zōt ay ka be namēd ay ka be drāyēd, ay ka kār-ē wizārdan šawēd hamāg yazišn sar

"According to all doctrines, when it happens that the zōt grows damp ort chatters or leaves to perform a task between the time when he has come to the initial frastuiiē (Y0.6) and the time when has reached the wāz gīrišnīh of the initial frastuiie, then the whole yazišn comes to an end."

ModernPractice.ab: "From here, the chief priest makes both hands wet in the pure water container and pouring a drop of water on the date-palm leaf of the bundle, circling the bundle with both hands over the moon-shaped stands, he recites while holding it (=the bundle) in the left hand: frauuarāne ... frasastaiiaēca. Recite here the dedication for whom the Yasna is to be performed. The dedication of Mīno Nāvar is given below: ahurahe ... frasastaiiaēca. The chief priest yaϑā ... mrūte. The assistant priest: yaϑā ... mrūte. The chief priest aϑā ratuš ... mraotū."

"Standing erect, with the barsom in the left hand and his right hand uplifted, the zōt recites with the rāspī another article of faith, the fravarānē ("I profess") [...] The rāspī offers sandalwood and frankincense (kūsh-bōy) to the fire, and both recite the Avestan dedication (khshnūman) to the spirit being (yazad) in whose honor the Yasna is being performed. [...] The zōt and rāspī exchange the antiphonal Avestan recitation called the bāj"
